statement:
Suppose that $C_1$ and $C_2$ are consequence operators on a set $L$ and
that, for every $X \subseteq L$, it happens that $C_1 (X) = X$ if and
only if $C_2 (X)
= X$. Then $C_1 = C_2$.

Suppose that $C$ is a consequence operators on a set $L$. Define
$K = \{ X 
\subseteq L \mid C(X) = X\}$. Then, for every $X \in L$, there exists a
$Y \in K$ such that $X \subseteq Y$ and, for every $Z \in K$ such that
$X \subseteq Z$, one has $Y \subseteq Z$.

Given a set $L$, suppose that $K$ is a subset of $L$ such that, for
every $X \in L$, there exists a $Y \in K$ such that $X \subseteq Y$ and,
for every $Z \in K$ such that $X \subseteq Z$, one has $Y \subseteq Z$.
Then there exists a consequence operator
$C \colon \mathcal{P}(L) \to \mathcal{P}(L)$ such that $C(X) = X$ if and
only if $X \in K$.
names: consequence operator is determined by its fixed points
